author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: ‘This Could Well Be Game Over’
description: The Supreme Court may well decide another presidential election.
content: While the Supreme Court ruling on Monday that states cannot bar Donald Trump from appearing on their presidential ballots garnered a lot of attention, the more politically consequential decision came on Feb. 28, when the court set a hearing on Trump’s claim of presidential immunity for the week of April 22.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: Apple Blocks Epic Games From Using iPhone Tools in Escalation of Feud
description: The move tests the European Union’s new tech competition law, which was designed to allow competing app stores.
content: When the European Union passed a 2022 law to loosen Apple’s grip on the app economy, Epic Games, the maker of Fortnite, began planning to launch a competing app store for developers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Denzel Washington and Jake Gyllenhaal to Lead Broadway ‘Othello’
description: Kenny Leon will direct a starry revival of Shakespeare’s tragedy in the spring of 2025.
content: Denzel Washington and Jake Gyllenhaal will star in a Broadway production of “Othello” next year, setting up what is sure to be one of the hottest tickets of the 2024-2025 theater season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Chair Powell Still Expects to Cut Rates This Year, but Not Yet
description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, told lawmakers that rate cuts in 2024 were still likely and that hot-button bank rules could be reissued.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, said on Wednesday that he thought the central bank would begin to lower borrowing costs in 2024 but that policymakers still needed to gain “greater confidence” that inflation was conquered before making a move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: Atom Bombs in Space Are Back to Scare Us Again
description: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin may find that a nuclear weapon in orbit is less useful for war than intimidation.
content: In 1982, President Ronald Reagan was considering what became known as “Star Wars,” a plan to shield America from Soviet missiles by deploying up to thousands of weapons in space. At the same time, as a young science writer, I was reporting on how the rays from a single nuclear detonation in orbit could wipe out whole fleets of battle stations and laser death rays. “Star Wars: Pentagon Lunacy,” read one of the headlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: John Kerry: ‘I Feel Deeply Frustrated’
description: The departing climate envoy on what the world has and hasn’t achieved.
content: When former Secretary of State John Kerry stepped into a newly created post as America’s top climate diplomat in 2021, the reputation of the United States abroad was, in his words, “in the crapper,” and the pathway to meeting the world’s climate goals looked, to most, very narrow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Bracing for a Trump Rematch, Biden Confronts Four Thorny Challenges
description: Before his State of the Union address, the president faces several political problems that are largely out of his control and present dangers to his re-election bid.
content: As he prepares to deliver the State of the Union address on Thursday, President Biden faces four intractable political problems that loom as hazards to his re-election campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mira Rojanasakul
title: New Data Details the Risk of Sea-Level Rise for U.S. Coastal Cities
description: A new study of sinking and rising land along American coasts offers a more specific understanding of potential flooding in 32 coastal cities.
content: A new study of sea-level rise using detailed data on changes to land elevation found that current scientific models may not accurately capture vulnerabilities in 32 coastal cities in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Maker of Raw Milk Cheese Pleads Guilty in Listeria Outbreak That Killed 2
description: The Food and Drug Administration linked cheese from the Vulto Creamery in Walton, N.Y., to an outbreak of listeria that also sickened six from 2016 to 2017.
content: A former raw milk cheese manufacturer and his company pleaded guilty on Tuesday in connection to an outbreak of listeria from 2016 to 2017 that killed two people and left six others hospitalized, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Cruise Ship Worker Accused of Hiding Cameras in Bathrooms to Spy on Guests
description: The former employee of Royal Caribbean told investigators that he had been secretly recording people since he started working there in December 2023. He faces federal and state charges.
content: A former employee of the cruise ship company Royal Caribbean was accused of placing cameras in guests’ bathrooms and of hiding in their bedrooms and recording them when they took off their clothes, with one of his reported targets being as young as 10.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Maltby
title: 5 Exercises We Hate, and Why You Should Do Them Anyway
description: Loathe burpees? Fear planks? Trainers share tips to make dreaded moves work for you.
content: Some exercise moves are easy, others are tough but manageable. But there are always a few that we truly abhor. Some are so reviled that they have their own merch with phrases like “Burpees Hate You Too.” If you’re not the “no pain, no gain” type, is it OK to just skip the burpee, or any of your other least favorite moves?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Donovan
title: The Best Dessert Mom Made for Us, but Better
description: Our house had the best treats in the neighborhood. This one we never shared.
content: In my mother’s kitchen, in the cabinet above the stove, lives a rectangle baking pan. It is chestnut brown, true to the 1970s, the decade she bought it as a young wife and new mother. It has knife scrapes along the bottom, spatula scratches along the sides, a few dents here and there from being packed and shipped and unpacked in countless kitchens, from the southern tip of Georgia to the middle of Bavaria. It is a talisman of my youth, a rare constant from the life of a wayward military brat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: eventuality
description: This word has appeared in 15 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word eventuality has appeared 15 times on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 25 in The New York Times Magazine article “Can Humans Endure the Psychological Torment of Mars?” by Nathaniel Rich:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: The 2020 Election Is Back
description: Donald J. Trump begins the 2024 general election campaign in the lead.
content: It’s Biden vs. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: ‘As Living as Opera Can Get’: John Cage’s Anarchic Anti-Canon
description: In his “Europeras,” Cage dismantled centuries of tradition and expectations, for musicians and audiences alike. A rare revival is coming to Detroit.
content: The start was typical: Oper Frankfurt in Germany asked John Cage to write an opera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Drake Bell Will Detail Abuse He Suffered as a Child Star
description: The former Nickelodeon actor is set to describe sexual abuse he experienced at the hands of a former dialogue coach, according to a new docuseries. Court documents detail the back story.
content: Jared Drake Bell, a former star of the hit Nickelodeon series “Drake & Josh,” will speak publicly about abuse he suffered at the hands of a 41-year-old dialogue coach when he was 15, according to the network airing a new docuseries about the grimmer aspects of children’s television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carla Sosenko
title: $1,780 to Spend the Night in a ‘Cocoon’? Hotels Are Betting on Sleep Tourism.
description: A.I.-assisted beds, on-call hypnotherapists and sequestered guest rooms, including one inside a stainless steel sculpture, are taking sleep tourism to the next level.
content: To sleep, perchance to dream. Or if not dream, at least to feel vaguely rested the next day, especially on vacation. Is that too much to ask?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: A Swimming Dinosaur? Maybe Not, Study Says
description: A new paper challenges the idea that the large, carnivorous Spinosaurus dived after prey rather than wading and plucking it out of the water.
content: Spinosaurus was one of the largest carnivorous dinosaurs, and it ate fish. That much paleontologists agree on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Why Won’t Our Daughter Introduce Us to Her New Boyfriend?
description: Parents who enjoy an otherwise close relationship with their 33-year-old daughter feel hurt not to have been introduced to a man she met three months ago and with whom she now lives.
content: Our only child is 33 and unmarried. We have a good relationship with her. She lives 30 minutes away from us, and we see her frequently. She met a man three months ago, and he has now moved in with her. The problem: We would love to meet him and become part of their lives together, but she says she is not ready to introduce us yet. We have tried to set up various opportunities to meet him, but she refuses. She says it’s not him, it’s her. She wants the encounter to be “perfect” and is anxious that it won’t be. I feel hurt! We try to avoid talking about him, but he soon becomes the elephant in the room. She says she’s an adult, and it’s her decision. Should we respect her privacy? She seems happy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Steve Garvey’s Improbable Rise, Decades After His Baseball Heyday
description: The former Major League Baseball star running for the Senate faces long odds in Democratic-run California. He hopes to appeal to voters who are frustrated — and love a good sports analogy.
content: For months after Steve Garvey joined the race for the Senate seat formerly held by Dianne Feinstein, voters in California were only dimly aware he was a candidate. A Republican long shot in a deeply Democratic state, the former Major League Baseball star seemed to be courting tens of millions of Californians in stealth mode: Scant press. Vague stances. No ads to speak of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: The Super Tuesday Shocker That Wasn’t: Biden Pulls Out a Tie in American Samoa
description: Jason Palmer, an entrepreneur from Maryland, was denied a win over President Biden due to a rounding error. He did secure three of the territory’s six delegates.
content: It looked at first like an embarrassing loss for a president struggling to rally his party behind him: For three hours on Tuesday night, President Biden appeared to have lost the Democratic caucus on a faraway Pacific island, American Samoa, to a little-known opponent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Haley Expected to Drop Out, and Bitcoin Completes Comeback
description: Plus, bad blood in Southeast Asia over Taylor Swift’s tour.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: John Walker, Tech Executive Who Popularized AutoCAD, Dies at 74
description: He avoided the spotlight, but he helped bring to market an explosively popular computer program that revolutionized the architecture and design industries.
content: John Walker, a groundbreaking, if reclusive, technology entrepreneur and polymath who was a founder and chief executive of Autodesk, the company that brought the ubiquitous AutoCAD software program to the design and architecture masses, died on Feb. 2 in Neuchâtel, Switzerland. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Gabriel García Márquez Wanted to Destroy His Last Novel. It’s About to Be Published.
description: The publication of “Until August” adds a surprising twist to his legacy, and may stir questions about posthumous releases that contradict a writer’s directives.
content: Toward the end of his life, when his memory was in pieces, Gabriel García Márquez struggled to finish a novel about the secret sex life of a married middle-age woman. He attempted at least five versions and tinkered with the text for years, slashing sentences, scribbling in the margins, changing adjectives, dictating notes to his assistant. Eventually, he gave up, and issued a final, devastating judgment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The New Rape Denialism
description: How quickly the far left pivots from “believe women” to “believe Hamas” when the identity of the victim changes.
content: On Oct. 7, Hamas invaded Israel and filmed itself committing scores of human-rights atrocities. Some of the footage was later captured by the Israeli military and screened to hundreds of journalists, including me. The “pure, predatory sadism,” as Atlantic writer Graeme Wood described it, is bottomless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: How Trump’s Crushing Primary Triumph Masked Quiet Weaknesses
description: Even though he easily defeated Nikki Haley, the primary results suggested that he still has long-term problems with suburban voters, moderates and independents.
content: Donald J. Trump’s daunting level of Republican support helped him vanquish a field of presidential primary rivals in under two months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan and Nate Schweber
title: Ex-President of Honduras Denies at Trial That He Trafficked Drugs
description: Juan Orlando Hernández, who is accused of conspiring to import cocaine into the United States, also denied receiving a bribe from the Mexican drug lord El Chapo.
content: The former two-term president of Honduras denied in court on Tuesday that he had trafficked narcotics, offered police protection to drug cartels or taken bribes — assertions that have been at the heart of a conspiracy trial taking place in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: In Showdown Over G.O.P. Control in Texas, the Race for House Speaker’s Seat Heads to a Runoff
description: Dade Phelan’s failure to secure his seat on Tuesday indicated that fights over the future direction of the Republican Party in Texas would continue roiling the state.
content: The Texas House speaker, Dade Phelan, and a local Republican activist backed by former President Donald J. Trump will compete in a runoff in May after neither received enough votes to win on Election Day, according to The Associated Press.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Nate Cohn, Rob Szypko, Mooj Zadie, Diana Nguyen, Rachel Quester, Diane Wong, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Unhappy Voters Who Could Swing the Election
description: In 2020 as in 2016, a potentially decisive slice of the electorate dislikes both main candidates. That could make for a volatile race.
content: Millions of voters in states across the country cast their ballots in the presidential primary on Super Tuesday, leaving little doubt that the November election will be a rematch between President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Ricky Stanicky’ Review: Best Fiends Forever
description: In this slapdash, off-color comedy directed by Peter Farrelly, three buddies use the same imaginary friend as an excuse to get them out of binds.
content: “Ricky Stanicky,” a sloppy shock comedy by the director Peter Farrelly (of the Oscar-winning “Green Book”), is named for an imaginary friend conjured up by three childhood pals (Zac Efron, Jermaine Fowler and Andrew Santino). As kids, the lads made their fictional buddy take the fall for a Halloween prank gone wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Sydney Ember
title: Do You Have Experience Working With Boeing? We Want to Hear From You.
description: Boeing’s quality control practices have been criticized after a panel on one of the company’s 737 Max jets blew open during a flight in January.
content: Two fatal crashes. Quality concerns and production slowdowns. A loose panel that blew out during a flight. Boeing is an American institution that has contributed to the country’s place on the global stage. But it is also weathering a particularly difficult period.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Alina Lobzina
title: Russians Flock to Navalny’s Grave as They Grapple With His Legacy
description: The loss of the optimism in the face of oppression espoused by Aleksei Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, has hit many Russians hard. Now, as one mourner said, “I don’t have any vision of the future.”
content: Marina, a Moscow lawyer, decided to stay home when the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny was buried last Friday. She had expected a big crowd and widespread arrests at the Borisovsky Cemetery, given Russia’s current climate of repression, and thought it would be better to pay her respects another day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Nadelson
title: Supper Clubs in New York Are a Vanishing Breed. Café Carlyle Is Keeping the Tradition Alive
description: Any night at the Upper East Side’s nearly 70-year-old cabaret still feels like a big night out.
content: On a Tuesday evening last December, the singer-pianist Michael Feinstein was at Café Carlyle on Manhattan’s Upper East Side in a sparkly silver blazer, making his way through the audience to the little stage, where the members of his four-piece band were taking their places. The audience erupted into applause. A few people stood and reached out a hand to greet him. As he launched into George and Ira Gershwin’s “Our Love Is Here to Stay,” some sang along, others swayed a little. Written in 1937, the American songbook standard is full of nostalgia, wit and romance. The same might be said for Café Carlyle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Mark Robinson Wins Republican Primary for North Carolina Governor
description: Mr. Robinson, the state’s lieutenant governor, had never run for office until 2020. He is a political firebrand whose harsh rhetoric could work for or against him.
content: Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson of North Carolina defeated his two challengers in the Republican primary for the governor’s race on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press. His win proved that his blustering, Trump-aligned style is favored by conservatives who are gearing up for what will probably be the most expensive and closely contested statewide race in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Lynsey Addario
title: Too Little Ammunition, Too Many Russians: The Harrowing Retreat From Avdiivka
description: The fall of the city, when it came in mid-February, was brutal and fast. Soldiers fought for their lives. Many did not make it.
content: The fighting had become increasingly ferocious last month at the Zenith air-defense base a mile south of Avdiivka, where for years a company of Ukrainian soldiers had defended the southern approaches to the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Inside America’s Shadow War With Iran
description: There’s another Middle East conflict going on, and U.S. soldiers are on the front lines of it.
content: It’s often been said that the most dangerous hot spot in the world is the waterway between Taiwan and mainland China, where the Chinese Navy and Air Force flex their muscles every day to try to intimidate Taiwan — while the U.S. Navy patrols nearby. I wonder. There is actually a stable balance of deterrence there right now. You could hold a friendly regatta in the Taiwan Straits compared to where I just visited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: The Privileges and Pitfalls of Making Movies About Real People
description: The Oscars slate this year is packed with films rooted in historical events and biographies. How much influence should the subjects have?
content: When Walter Naegle was first approached over a decade ago by producers who wanted to make a feature about his late partner, the civil rights leader Bayard Rustin, Naegle needed to be talked into it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Expecting Protests at the Oscars, Police Plan to Beef Up Security
description: The Los Angeles police said it would increase its presence at the Academy Awards, given the potential for protests related to the Israel-Hamas war.
content: The Los Angeles police said it would increase its presence at the Academy Awards on Sunday night to make sure that potential protests related to the Israel-Hamas war do not disrupt the Oscars ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: Seeing Stars, Sperm and Millions of Spawn After a Valentine’s Day Rendezvous
description: Sunflower sea stars, a species of giant starfish, are critically endangered. Researchers tinkered with sperm in an aquarium lab to help them reproduce.
content: On Valentine’s Day, Melissa Torres strung up red tinsel hearts around a shallow pool at her workplace, the Birch Aquarium at Scripps Institution of Oceanography in La Jolla, Calif. She and her colleagues were arranging a romantic encounter of sorts, and the stakes were high. The happy couple, a pair of sunflower sea stars, belonged to a species that has nearly vanished because of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Rain Douses New York and Southern New England
description: As a storm drenched the coastal Northeast, officials warned of heavy rain on Wednesday night and Thursday morning.
content: More than 30 million people were under a flood watch from Wednesday evening as a large coastal storm threatened New York City, Boston and other parts of the coastal Northeast, forecasters said, and commuters were cautioned to expect travel disruptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sella
title: Israel Rejects Far-Right Plan for New Limits on Access to Important Mosque
description: As the Muslim holy month of Ramadan approaches, the move may reduce tensions at the Aqsa Mosque compound, which has long been a flashpoint for unrest.
content: The Israeli government has decided against putting new restrictions on access to an important mosque in Jerusalem during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, a move that may reduce tensions at a site that has long been a flashpoint for unrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: ‘This Is the Best Dinner I’ve Ever Made’
description: “This meal was simple, healthy, and so incredibly tasty. I’d eat this every night of my life,” a reader says of my sheet-pan chicken with garlic yogurt.
content: We’ve had a few glorious days of faux spring here in New York City, a balmy omen of sunshine to come. Only a few short weeks of winter to go!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: OpenAI Says Elon Musk Tried to Merge It With Tesla
description: In its first public comment since Mr. Musk sued the artificial intelligence lab, OpenAI claims he tried to commercialize its operations years ago.
content: OpenAI, in its first public comments about Elon Musk’s lawsuit against the influential artificial intelligence research lab, said Mr. Musk had tried to transform the lab from a nonprofit into a for-profit operation before he left the organization in early 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Colleen Hagerty
title: Protesters Interrupt Adam Schiff’s Victory Speech, Chanting ‘Cease-Fire Now’
description: The California Democrat was thrilled by Tuesday’s election results, but his celebration was tempered by protests of his support of Israel.
content: Representative Adam Schiff got everything he wanted on Super Tuesday: not only a first-place finish in the primary for a California Senate seat, but also his preferred general-election opponent in second place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Mike Baker
title: ‘Uncommitted’ Effort to Protest Biden Will Shift Its Focus to Washington State
description: The campaign is urging Democrats to register their discontent with President Biden’s handling of the war in Gaza by voting “uncommitted.” Washington’s primary is on Tuesday.
content: After gaining some traction in Michigan and Minnesota, the next stop in the campaign to protest President Biden’s handling of Israel’s war in Gaza will be the Washington State primary next Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 6, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, March 6, 2024.
content: An article on Tuesday about a U.N. investigation of sexual violence during the Oct. 7, 2023, attack on Israel misattributed the source of several quotes about the U.N. investigation. The quotes were taken from a U.N. statement summarizing the report, not from the report itself. The full report is linked from the article online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: You Don’t Need a Greenhouse to Grow Citrus Indoors
description: ‘Lemons and limes are really great houseplants,’ said the owner of a rare-plants nursery in Connecticut — if you choose the right ones.
content: Shattering the glass ceiling isn’t always a goal — not if you’re a certain beloved lemon tree growing in a Victorian-era greenhouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Schiff and Garvey Advance in the California Senate Race for Feinstein’s Seat
description: Representative Adam Schiff, a prominent antagonist of former President Donald J. Trump, will face Steve Garvey, a Republican former baseball star, in a November runoff.
content: Representative Adam Schiff, the lead prosecutor in Donald J. Trump’s first impeachment trial, and Steve Garvey, a former Major League Baseball star, advanced on Tuesday night to the California general election for a Senate seat, according to The Associated Press.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Belle Burden
title: The Babe Paley in ‘Feud’ Is Not the Woman I Knew
description: In a popular TV show, my grandmother is fictionalized as one of Truman Capote’s swans. I wish she’d had the chance to tell her story in her way.
content: The first time I saw Naomi Watts playing my grandmother Babe Paley in “Feud: Capote vs. the Swans,” she was in tears. She had just discovered her husband’s affair with Happy Rockefeller, the governor’s wife, finding him on the bedroom floor, scrubbing a stain of menstrual blood from their plush carpet. Babe summons Truman Capote to her Fifth Avenue apartment, her face set in distress, her mascara running. He tries to comfort her, handing her a Valium, reminding her that her marital arrangement is still worth it; she can buy a Matisse to soothe her broken heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons
title: International Court Accuses 2 Russian Officers of War Crimes in Ukraine
description: Arrest warrants were issued by the International Criminal Court for two military officials, a general and an admiral, both accused of targeting civilians and destroying crucial energy infrastructure.
content: The International Criminal Court on Tuesday issued arrest warrants for two top Russian military officers, accusing them of war crimes in Ukraine for targeting civilians and destroying crucial energy infrastructure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: U.K. to Cut Taxes Again as Election Nears
description: The Conservative government, trailing badly in the polls, proposed the second tax cut in four months.
content: Amid lackluster prospects for economic growth, the British government announced it would cut taxes for workers ahead of a general election this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Scientists Create Elephant Stem Cells in the Lab
description: The results could shed light on why the animals rarely get cancer. But the researchers’ ultimate goal of bringing back woolly mammoths is still aspirational.
content: When the biotechnology firm Colossal started in 2021, it set an eyebrow-raising goal: to genetically engineer elephants with hair and other traits found on extinct woolly mammoths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Barron, Lynn Levy, Sophia Lanman and Alissa Wilkinson
title: A Best-Actor Nominee Who Could Make Oscar History
description: Our critic on Colman Domingo in “Rustin.”
content: Even if you don’t know Colman Domingo’s name, you probably know his face. The actor has established himself as one of Hollywood’s most compelling character actors with standout performances in TV shows like “Euphoria” and films like “If Beale Street Could Talk” and “The Color Purple.” But now, Domingo is making the leap to leading man. He was nominated for an Oscar this year for his portrayal of the civil rights leader Bayard Rustin in “Rustin.” His best-actor nomination isn’t just a significant career milestone, it could also be a milestone for Hollywood: If he wins, Domingo will be the first openly gay man to win an Oscar for playing an openly gay character. Our movie critic Alissa Wilkinson discusses Domingo’s star turn and where it fits in Hollywood history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Comforting Rice Dish That Won’t Break the Bank
description: Adas polo, a Persian recipe perfumed with cinnamon and layered with caramelized onions and dates, only feels expensive.
content: A bowl of lentils and rice is essential comfort food across so many cultures, be it South Asian khichdi, Middle Eastern mujadara or Greek fakorizo. No matter how traditional recipes differ, combining lentils and rice always results in a dish that’s thrifty, hearty and infinitely adaptable, inspiring as many appealing variations as there are inventive cooks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Promised Calm After Trump Chaos, but the World Has Not Cooperated
description: Inflation, an explosion of migration at the border and wars in Europe and the Middle East have created a sense of instability that polls show have eroded his support.
content: During the 2020 campaign, Joseph R. Biden Jr. denounced Donald J. Trump as “an incumbent president who sows chaos rather than providing order.” After defeating Mr. Trump, Mr. Biden told the nation in his Inaugural Address that he would reverse the “state of chaos” that he had inherited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Who Is Mark Robinson, the Republican Nominee for North Carolina Governor?
description: Mr. Robinson formally entered politics in 2019, when he began his run for lieutenant governor. He has appeared eager to drive divisions, disparaging L.G.B.T.Q. people and quoting Hitler on social media.
content: Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson of North Carolina secured the Republican nomination for governor on Tuesday, continuing his rapid political rise in a key battleground state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Trump’s Conquest of the Republican Party Matters to Every American
description: Donald Trump has used the presidential primaries to purge his party of dissent. Republicans have lost the capacity to serve as a check on his power.
content: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.
source.name: The New York Times

title: girl in red: The Popcast (Deluxe) Interview
description: An interview with the Norwegian singer girl in red (Marie Ulven) about her second album, “I’m Doing It Again Baby!,” opening for Taylor Swift and more.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, features an interview with the Norwegian indie-pop star girl in red (Marie Ulven) — whose second album, “I’m Doing It Again Baby!,” is out April 12 — in conversation about:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: The Election is Set
description: The primaries are effectively over —  and the general election begins.
content: It’s Biden vs. Trump. It’ll be a few weeks before they have enough delegates to clinch their nominations, but after yesterday’s Super Tuesday results — in which those candidates won at least 14 states each — the primaries are effectively over. The general election is about to begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: Christopher Walken’s Hidden ‘Dune’ Connection
description: The actor who plays the malevolent emperor in the new film actually brought an element of the saga to life once before. Remember “Weapon of Choice”?
content: If you turned on MTV for any length of time in 2001, you almost certainly saw Christopher Walken flying around the lobby of a Marriott in Los Angeles. Even in an era when music videos were far more hotly discussed than they are now, it was a weird sight. Walken’s trim shock of gray hair matched his gray suit, punctuated by a red tie; he looked less like the movie star he was than some guy on a long layover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Reid J. Epstein
title: ‘Uncommitted’ Draws Strong Support Against Biden in Minnesota
description: The effort to pressure the president over his support for Israel garnered a sizable share of the vote, despite being more hastily organized. Voters in other states also voiced unease.
content: The movement objecting to President Biden’s position on Israel by voting “uncommitted” drew a significant share of the vote on Tuesday in Minnesota despite having a hastily organized and low-budget campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Please, President Biden: Don’t Blame Corporate Greed for Inflation
description: Instead of casting blame, Biden should tout what he’s done to ease Americans’ financial pressures.
content: I hope President Biden doesn’t show up for his State of the Union address on Thursday with a Snickers bar. Politico reported last month that Biden abruptly asked people at a dinner whether they had “seen that article about the Snickers bars,” an apparent reference to this guest essay in The Times about why voters are so upset about inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Israel Must Let More Aid Into Gaza, U.K. Tells Israeli Official
description: After meeting with Benny Gantz, a member of Israel’s war cabinet, the British foreign secretary, David Cameron, had strong words about conditions in Gaza that “must change.”
content: Meeting with a member of Israel’s war cabinet on Wednesday, Britain’s foreign secretary said Israel must help get far more food and other supplies into the Gaza Strip to address the humanitarian crisis there, the secretary said after they spoke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Chappel
title: We’re Not Asking the Most Important Questions About Age
description: A presidential contest between two older candidates is an opportunity for us to start recognizing the crucial needs of our aging population.
content: After President Biden delivers his third State of the Union address on Thursday, much of the analysis will focus on the apparent signs of the president’s age. How alert does he seem? How spry? Does he look up to the task of running for office, or of governing? Questions like these certainly matter, but they are not the only ones we should be asking about age and aging right now. They are not even the most important.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Maria Abi-Habib
title: Haiti Engulfed by Crisis as Gangs Press Prime Minister to Step Down
description: The power struggle in Haiti is raising pressure on the United States to ease tensions while casting doubt on plans for a Kenyan-led security mission.
content: Haiti’s security crisis is reaching a breaking point. An alliance of armed gangs is pressing the country’s prime minister to resign, placing the United States in the middle of a power struggle gripping the country. Aiming to ease the standoff, the Biden administration is increasing pressure on Prime Minister Ariel Henry to enable a transfer of power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: With Sweeping New Laws, Louisiana Embraces Tough-on-Crime Approach
description: Gov. Jeff Landry is enacting stringent new measures that he says are crucial to address crime; critics say the laws resemble failed policies of the past.
content: In 2017, Louisiana overhauled its criminal justice system with broad bipartisan support, all in an effort to lose the distinction of having the nation’s highest incarceration rate. Sentences were reduced. Opportunities for parole were expanded. Alternatives to prison were introduced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Michael D. Shear
title: Ukraine’s First Lady Declines Invitation to State of the Union Address
description: Olena Zelenska’s office cited a scheduling conflict. The Russian opposition figure Yulia Navalnaya also declined an invitation.
content: Olena Zelenska, Ukraine’s first lady, declined a White House invitation to attend President Biden’s State of the Union address on Thursday, her office said, citing a scheduling conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Two Democrats emerge from a crowded field in a newly competitive House district in Alabama.
description: Shomari Figures, a former Justice Department official, and State Representative Anthony Daniels will head to a runoff election in the Democratic primary in the Second Congressional District.
content: Shomari Figures, a former Justice Department official, and State Representative Anthony Daniels will head to a runoff election in the Democratic primary for Alabama’s Second Congressional District, according to The Associated Press.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden Preps for the State of the Union Speech and Rowdy Republicans
description: The speech, which will be edited up until the president delivers it, will be watched by one of his biggest audiences before the November election.
content: Fueled by throat-soothing tea, guided by teleprompters and surrounded by six aides and one historian, President Biden spent hours at Camp David last weekend honing a State of the Union speech that will be watched by one of his biggest audiences before the November election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Republicans’ Dilemma on Mayorkas Impeachment: When to Take the Loss
description: House Republicans rushed to impeach the homeland security secretary but are taking their time delivering the charges to the Senate, where a trial is likely to be over before it begins — or yield a quick acquittal.
content: After approving impeachment articles against Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, that are doomed in the Senate, House Republicans are facing a confounding question: How — and when — do you take a political loss in the least embarrassing way?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Who Won, Who Lost and What’s Still Undecided From Super Tuesday
description: The presidential candidates weren’t the only ones on the ballot.
content: Donald J. Trump and President Biden emerged victorious from Super Tuesday, the biggest day in the primary season, with only Nikki Haley’s narrow victory in Vermont helping her avoid a shutout in the 15 Republican contests. She was expected to end her campaign on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Something to Bat Around
description: Brad Wiegmann figures he can trick us. And he does.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines and Colbi Edmonds
title: Federal Judge Rules Minority Business Agency Must Serve White People as Well
description: The ruling, by a judge in Texas, was the latest in a string of court decisions that have eroded or struck down federal affirmative-action mandates in a variety of arenas.
content: The Minority Business Development Agency, a Commerce Department program created during the Nixon administration to help minority-owned businesses, discriminates against white people and must offer its services to people of all races and ethnic groups, a federal judge in Texas ruled on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: Steven Mnuchin Backs New York Community Bank in $1 Billion Deal
description: Mr. Mnuchin, the former Treasury secretary, led investors who put together a package in an effort to rescue the struggling lender.
content: Former Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin swooped in to rescue New York Community Bank on Wednesday, leading a group of investors who injected more than $1 billion into a lender flailing from its exposure to a softening real estate market and internal management mistakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: With Haley’s Departure, the Rematch Between Biden and Trump Is Now Set
description: The contest that many Americans had long hoped to avoid — the 2024 sequel of Biden vs. Trump — is an inescapable reality.
content: The exit by Nikki Haley from the Republican primary after a string of resounding losses on Super Tuesday assured former President Donald J. Trump of his party’s nomination, kicking off a general election contest with President Biden that both sides expect will be bitter, brutal and long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: Lucid Dreaming, Person to Person
description: In Ursula Eagly’s “Dream Body Body Building” at the Chocolate Factory, the dancers seem to be transmitting a dream state to the audience.
content: For the first stretch of “Dream Body Body Building” at the Chocolate Factory Theater, five performers in a row of folding chairs sit facing the audience, almost entirely still.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Full Transcript of Nikki Haley’s Remarks as She Dropped Out of G.O.P. Primary
description: Nikki Haley wished Donald J. Trump well, but she did not endorse him.
content: Nikki Haley suspended her presidential run on Wednesday morning, delivering remarks at her headquarters on Daniel Island in South Carolina. The following is a transcript of her remarks, as recorded by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: On a Bright Night for His Campaign, Trump Again Conjures a Dark Vision
description: As he dominated the Super Tuesday battlefield, former President Donald Trump warned of dark days ahead if President Biden were to win a second term. “We’re a third-world country,” he said repeatedly.
content: Despite dominating the Super Tuesday nominating contests, former President Donald J. Trump gave a victory speech short on celebration or exultation and long on sinister evocations of what he portrayed as a grim fate for the country if President Biden is re-elected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa, Jonathan Weisman and Ruth Fremson
title: Haley’s Failed Campaign Highlights G.O.P. Rifts and Trump’s Dominance
description: Falling well short in a spirited campaign to dethrone Mr. Trump, Ms. Haley brought to a close the latest struggle over the soul and direction of the Republican Party.
content: After absorbing bruising losses in the Super Tuesday primaries, Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina, announced on Wednesday that she was ending her presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles W. McFarlane
title: Fresh Faces for Old Gear
description: A new generation of military surplus business owners takes an internet-savvy approach to hyping their merchandise.
content: On a chilly afternoon in February, Logan McGrath and Mack Fritz were preparing to shoot a video advertising the green Austrian army fatigue shirts they were selling on Americana Pipedream Apparel, the online military surplus store Mr. McGrath started out of his parents’ basement in Appleton, Wis., three years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: Venezuela Announces Election Date, With Opposition Candidate Still Banned
description: The decision to hold a vote on July 28 is a partial fulfillment of a commitment to the United States, but with the top opposition figure barred, many wondered how free and fair the balloting would be.
content: Venezuelan officials announced on Tuesday that national elections that many had hoped would forge a path toward democracy will be held on July 28.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Before N.Y.C. Snow Day Debacle, IBM Had Warned of Tech Limitations
description: Technical failures blocked thousands of students who tried to log on to school during a snowstorm. At a City Council hearing on Wednesday, an IBM official said it wasn’t the company’s fault.
content: When New York City held virtual classes during a winter storm last month, the system ran into major tech problems. But officials unfairly blamed IBM for the debacle, according to a company representative and several City Council members who spoke at a hearing on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Davis Land, Jen Poyant, Paula Szuchman, Daniel Ramirez, Kate LoPresti, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker and Marion Lozano
title: Novelist Celeste Ng on the Big Power of Little Things
description: The acclaimed author delves into a Modern Love essay about parenting, poetry and persistence.
content: Before Celeste Ng became a best-selling author, she had a side hustle selling miniatures on eBay — dollhouse-size recreations of food were her specialty. Even after the publication of “Little Fires Everywhere,” “Everything I Never Told You,” and, most recently, “Our Missing Hearts,” Celeste still makes tiny things — now, as a hobby. She’s come to realize the parallels between making small things and writing: Both give her a chance to look closely at the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Zerofsky
title: Why Power Eludes the French Left
description: France has often been the vanguard of leftist politics — but support in the streets doesn’t always translate to votes at the ballot box.
content: The signs that a protest is happening in Paris are nearly always the same: the quiet of blocked-off streets; the neat rows of police vans containing the gendarmerie stretching down the boulevard; the sound of drumbeats and whistles and the neon red flares that spit smoke into the sky. For six months last year, those signs were constant and ubiquitous, as furious, sometimes violent marches and general strikes protesting President Emmanuel Macron’s pension reforms brought Paris to a standstill. Students and activists, public-transit operators, custodial staff, medics, mechanics, teachers, oil-rig workers, writers and celebrities all gathered to rail against Macron’s plan to raise the national retirement age by two years, to 64.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Marilynne Robinson
description: The March 5, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Marilynne Robinson. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Senegal’s Leader Breaks Up Cabinet and Sets Date for Presidential Election
description: President Macky Sall previously postponed the election without setting a date. On Wednesday, he also fired the prime minister, his party’s candidate for president.
content: President Macky Sall of Senegal on Wednesday dissolved his cabinet, replaced the prime minister and rescheduled the country’s presidential election to March 24, according to a government statement. The move came weeks after Mr. Sall postponed the ballot indefinitely, throwing the country into one of its deepest political crises in recent history as many feared he might try to stay in power past his term limit.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: She Boxes. She Conducts. She Defies Stereotypes.
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, March 6, 2024.
content: “I wanted to have a magic wand, and I wanted to do something crazy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Houston’s District Attorney Concedes in Democratic Primary
description: The incumbent, Kim Ogg, had made herself a lightning rod within her party by tacking to the center and clashing with fellow Democrats.
content: Sean Teare, a former prosecutor and first-time candidate who promised new approaches to handling low-level criminal cases, defeated Kim Ogg, the two-term district attorney in Harris County, Texas, in the Democratic primary on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: After Super Tuesday, Trump Is Stronger Than He’s Ever Been
description: A rule of the Trump era: The lower his profile, the higher his polls.
content: About 18 months ago, Donald Trump suffered one of his worst political defeats, when many of his loyalists and handpicked candidates were defeated in a midterm landscape that clearly favored the Republicans. A lot of people — I was one of them — thought that this might be the beginning of the end for him, a stark indicator of political weakness that would encourage G.O.P. voters to abandon him or set him up for a decisive general election defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen and Yiwen Lu
title: The Youths Have Spoken: Wallets Are Uncool. Go Digital.
description: A wallet-free lifestyle relying on your phone is attainable, but it requires preparation and some compromise.
content: To a growing number of youths, a wallet stuffed with cash and cards is as unfashionable as the millennial tuck, no-show socks and skinny jeans. Carrying only a smartphone is the way. Iykyk — that’s “if you know, you know,” for those who don’t know.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Alabama’s I.V.F. Protection Law Will Reopen Clinics but Curb Patient Rights
description: Here’s what to know about the legislation, which the Legislature approved overwhelmingly on Wednesday.
content: The Alabama legislature on Wednesday approved legislation intended to make it possible for fertility clinics in the state to reopen without the specter of crippling lawsuits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Dean Phillips Halts Long-Shot Presidential Bid
description: Mr. Phillips, President Biden’s most significant Democratic rival, had argued that voters wanted a younger alternative to the president. But his candidacy stalled soon after he entered the race.
content: Representative Dean Phillips of Minnesota suspended his long-shot campaign for the Democratic nomination on Wednesday and endorsed President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Josh Stein Wins Democratic Primary for North Carolina Governor
description: Mr. Stein, the state attorney general, easily defeated four primary opponents and will likely face Mark Robinson, the Republican lieutenant governor, in November.
content: Josh Stein, the North Carolina attorney general, handily won the state’s Democratic primary for governor on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, setting the stage for a matchup with a fiery Republican rival in a race that will be tightly contested and closely watched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Andrew Cuomo Faces House Subpoena Over Covid Deaths in Nursing Homes
description: Mr. Cuomo was accused of stonewalling a House subcommittee trying to interview him about his administration’s handling of nursing homes during the Covid pandemic.
content: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has been subpoenaed to appear before a House subcommittee to answer for his administration’s handling of nursing homes during the coronavirus pandemic, reigniting a flashpoint that could further damage his chances at a political comeback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Takeaways From the Texas Primary: Ken Paxton Ousts Some of His Enemies
description: The Republican attorney general succeeded in defeating some politicians and judges who opposed him. But Democrats showed they also know how to punish incumbents.
content: The primary election in Texas on Tuesday was among the most expensive and hard-fought in state history, as factions of the Republican Party battled for control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck, Anjali Huynh and Caroline Gutman
title: With Haley Out of the Race, What Will Her Voters Do in November?
description: Nikki Haley’s supporters tend to be moderate and college educated, the type of voters who have helped decide recent presidential races. The New York Times spoke with nearly 40 in February to see where they were leaning.
content: Many Americans are dreading a Trump-Biden rematch, but no one feels the anguish quite like a Nikki Haley voter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Onstage in Chicago, Zach Bryan Howled, and the Crowd Found Its Voice
description: The singer and songwriter has become one of pop’s least expected new stars. On opening night of his arena tour, he showcased the bond with his fans that brought him there.
content: The first two songs Zach Bryan played at the United Center on Tuesday night were from the more muscular end of his catalog. They landed hard and quick — Bryan was singing with a rugged howl, guitars were churning, the fiddle poked through the top like a squeal. This was opening night of The Quittin Time Tour, and the first of three sold-out shows here, and he was wasting no time pumping the audience into a frenzy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Philadelphia Man Is Freed After 34 Years in Prison
description: Police had hidden evidence showing that Ronald Johnson did not participate in the crime he was convicted of, his lawyer said.
content: Ronald Johnson, who had spent more than three decades behind bars, was freed on Monday after a Philadelphia judge vacated his sentence and reversed his conviction, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Ana Ley
title: National Guard and State Police Will Patrol the Subways and Check Bags
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul, amid a series of violent crimes on the subway, said she would deploy 1,000 members of the State Police and National Guard to the transit system.
content: Hundreds of National Guard soldiers and State Police officers will patrol the New York City subway platforms and check riders’ bags beginning this week, Gov. Kathy Hochul said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: Was Trump’s Nomination Always Inevitable?
description: As recently as a year ago, less than half of Republican voters named Trump as their preferred candidate.
content: Nikki Haley’s exit from the presidential race this morning all but assures former President Donald Trump of the Republican nomination, in a contest that has been notably lacking in suspense. But that wasn’t always the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nada Rashwan
title: I.M.F. Agrees to Much Larger Rescue Package for Egypt
description: The International Monetary Fund will provide $8 billion to Egypt, which is going through its worst economic crisis in decades.
content: The International Monetary Fund has agreed to more than double a bailout package for Egypt, which is going through its worst economic crisis in decades, exacerbated by war in the neighboring Gaza Strip and in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: How to Fix the Crisis of Trust in Higher Education
description: Start listening to students about what makes college relevant.
content: Since the beginning of the year, I’ve been keeping track of every report I see about major budget shortfalls at universities. The general trend seems to be that the schools facing these shortfalls have declining enrollments, and state and federal funding is not meeting the financial gaps left by fewer students. Every week it seems there’s fresh bad news. Here’s a sampling:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Finds Super Tuesday Super Predictable
description: “Spoiler: It’s Biden/Trump,” Stephen Colbert said. “It’s always been Biden/Trump. It will always be Biden/Trump.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Felder
title: Lucien Pellat-Finet, Fashion’s ‘King of Cashmere,’ Dies at 78
description: The aesthetic of the sweaters he designed, which included provocative symbols like marijuana leaves and skulls, was casual. Their price tags were not.
content: Lucien Pellat-Finet, the French fashion designer whose brash, irreverent and unapologetically expensive sweaters earned him the nickname King of Cashmere, died on Feb. 26 in Trancoso, Brazil, where he had owned a home for more two decades. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: A big day in American politics.
content: Super Tuesday, during which millions of U.S. voters went to the polls for primaries in 15 states, indicated that Americans will likely face a presidential rematch between two deeply unpopular candidates in 2024: Donald Trump vs. President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: A Window Into Chinese Government Has Now Slammed Shut
description: Once a year, the premier held a news conference, explaining the economy and giving Chinese a taste of political participation. That has come to an end.
content: For more than 30 years, the Chinese premier’s annual news conference was the only time that a top leader took questions from journalists about the state of the country. It was the only occasion for members of the public to size up for themselves China’s No. 2 official. It was the only moment when some Chinese might feel a faint sense of political participation in a country without elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Democratic Congressional Candidate in Michigan to Air First I.V.F. Ad of Election Cycle
description: The spot provides a glimpse of how Democrats plan to make the issue of access to fertility treatments central to campaigns across the country.
content: Voters in Michigan on Friday will see the first television advertisement of the campaign cycle featuring a Democratic candidate for Congress talking about her experience using I.V.F. to start a family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: For Casting Directors, the Hunt for a Killer Never Stops
description: Procedural dramas are often relaxing to watch, but the hectic sprint to find and cast new patients, clients and crooks each week is anything but.
content: On a Monday afternoon in February, Findley Davidson and Jonathan Tolins met for a video call. Tolins, the showrunner for the new CBS procedural “Elsbeth,” and Davidson, the show’s casting director, were finalizing casting for the sixth episode, which visits the offices of an exclusive plastic surgeon, and discussing the seventh, which attends a country club wedding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi, Ephrat Livni and David Gelles
title: S.E.C. Approves New Climate Rules Far Weaker Than Originally Proposed
description: The rules, designed to inform investors of business risks from climate change, were rolled back amid opposition from the G.O.P., fossil fuel producers, farmers and others.
content: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved new rules on Wednesday detailing if and how public companies should disclose climate risks and how much greenhouse gas emissions they produce, but there are fewer demands on businesses than the original proposal made about two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Nikki Haley Wins Vermont, Her Second Victory Against Trump
description: The win signals her limited strength in places with large numbers of younger people, college-educated voters and independents.
content: Nikki Haley won the Republican primary in Vermont, according to The Associated Press, notching her second victory of the 2024 campaign and her first — and perhaps only — win in a Super Tuesday state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Spouse Is the Breadwinner. How Should We Divvy Assets in the Divorce?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to equitably divide marital assets after a split.
content: I have been married for eight years, and I’m starting the process of divorce. In the beginning of the marriage, we contributed equally to the household expenses. Over the last few years, I have cut back my hours and have taken lower-paying, more meaningful work. In the meantime, my spouse has had increased responsibility and pay at work. She has taken on most of the household expenses. We have discussed changing our lifestyle in order to allow her to get a less-stressful, lower-paying job, but she decided not to pursue that. Additionally, she has been financially generous with my grown children from a previous marriage, helping to pay for weddings and down payments on homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: The Very Busy Writer Telling Everyone to Slow Down
description: In his eighth book, the best-selling author Cal Newport offers life hacks for producing high-quality work while working less.
content: About halfway through his new book, “Slow Productivity: The Lost Art of Accomplishment Without Burnout,” Cal Newport presents the example of Galileo, whose summertime visits to a villa near Padua gave him a chance to rest and reflect between scientific pursuits. “Once there,” Newport writes, “he would take long walks in the hills and enjoy sleeping in a room ingeniously air-conditioned by a series of ducts that carried in cool air from a nearby cave system.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sella, Helene Cooper and Thomas Fuller
title: Israel Sees Vindication in U.N.’s Report, but Tensions Between Them Rise
description: A U.N. inquiry found support for Israel’s allegations of sexual violence in the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack, but they remain bitterly at odds over the war in the Gaza Strip.
content: Israelis largely welcomed a U.N. report that supported allegations of sexual violence during the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack, even as a top Israeli official accused the United Nations of not doing enough to address the findings — a sign of the rising tensions between them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Courtney Cox and Francesca Paris
title: When Caitlin Clark Comes to Town
description: Measures of her star power include huge jumps in attendance at road games, and the logistical planning required.
content: What happens when Caitlin Clark comes to town?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: One Twin Was Hurt, the Other Was Not. Their Adult Mental Health Diverged.
description: A large study of “discordant twins,” in which only one suffered abuse or neglect, adds to evidence linking childhood trauma to adult illness.
content: Twins are a bonanza for research psychologists. In a field perpetually seeking to tease out the effects of genetics, environment and life experience, they provide a natural controlled experiment as their paths diverge, subtly or dramatically, through adulthood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Harvard’s Response to Subpoenas Is Called ‘Useless’ by House Committee
description: Harvard said it has been acting in good faith and submitted thousands of pages of new material.
content: Representative Virginia Foxx, who is leading a House investigation of campus antisemitism, blasted Harvard University on Tuesday for handing over “useless” documents in response to subpoenas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Why Don’t More American Maestros Lead American Orchestras?
description: Leonard Bernstein blazed a trail for conductors from the United States nearly 70 years ago. But at top American orchestras these days, they’re scarce.
content: When Leonard Bernstein was named music director of the New York Philharmonic in 1958, his appointment was hailed as a breakthrough for orchestra conductors from the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof and Jillian Weinberger
title: The Answer to America’s Addiction Crisis Could Come Out of Tulsa
description: Nicholas Kristof on the most effective recovery program he’s ever seen.
content: Nicholas Kristof has spent a lot of time reporting on addiction. “My own community in Oregon has suffered a great deal from it. I’ve lost a lot of friends to it,” he says. In a recent trip to Tulsa, Okla., Kristof visited Women in Recovery, an addiction treatment program showing what’s possible. In this audio essay, he introduces us to a program graduate, Katelyn Fullbright, who struggled with cocaine and meth addiction but now holds a full-time job she enjoys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Review: For ‘Jack Tucker,’ Failure Is the Only Option
description: Zach Zucker delivers a raucously funny portrait of a catastrophically dim stand-up comic at SoHo Playhouse.
content: In one of his most quotable lyrics, Bob Dylan sang about a woman who knows “there’s no success like failure/ And that failure’s no success at all.” She clearly never saw the comedy of Jack Tucker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What Is Teenage Bullying Like Today?
description: An Opinion columnist writes that meanness among teenagers hasn’t gone away, it’s just gotten more stealthy. Do you agree?
content: Have you ever watched an old high school movie — say, “Mean Girls,” “The Breakfast Club” or “Clueless” — and been shocked by the insults the teenagers in the film hurled at one another? Did they use names and terms that you and your friends wouldn’t dare use today?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Josette Molland’s Testimony: Scenes of Life in Nazi Camps
description: In her 80s, she created a series of paintings depicting the horrors she endured in forced-labor camps during World War II.
content: Josette Molland, who died at 100 in France on Feb. 17, was a young member of the French Resistance during World War II when she was captured by the Gestapo and imprisoned in Nazi forced-labor camps for women. She survived, after witnessing and enduring repeated episodes of brutality. Later, after her return to France, she spoke to students about her experiences for years.

content: There were cocktails, and there were sliders. There were pop hits played by a D.J. at The Bungalow, a midcentury-modern lounge in Long Beach, Calif., where Representative Katie Porter had gathered supporters after more than a year of campaigning for a coveted Senate seat.

title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Don Cherry

content: Of all the musicians we’ve featured in this series, Don Cherry might be the most adventurous. From his early days in the late 1950s playing with the saxophonist Ornette Coleman to his tinkering with electronic funk and R&B in the ’80s, Cherry proved himself a worthy anarchist, broadening the depth of his art through the wind of his pocket cornet, an instrument he popularized. Though with Cherry, there was a sense that he didn’t want to shift the genre as a whole. Instead, his music felt innocent and voyeuristic, like he colored outside the lines just because.

Remember when the Canadian musician known as Grimes — former partner of one of the world’s most powerful men, the tech entrepreneur Elon Musk — brought a sword to the 2021 Met Gala? The image of a futurist pop star lugging a medieval blade (made from a smelted AR-15, no less) down the red carpet summed up the mystifying way contemporary culture seems to run in all directions, chasing myths both new and old.

We want to know what Robinson thinks of Genesis for the same reason we’d want to know what Tolstoy thought of it.
